item.title: Introduction to information theoretic measures
item.description: The mutual information is a measure of the dependency between two random variables in the most general sense. It is agnostic to the nature of the random variables and of their relationship : noted $\operatorname{I}(X;Y)$, it simply defines the quantity of information one knows about $X$ by knowing $Y$, and vice-versa. It was introduced by Claude Shannon in 1948 to characterize communication channels (Citation: Shannon, 1948Shannon,  C.   (1948).  A mathematical theory of communication.
